The pressure or weight of the atmosphere, as shown by the barOmetar, the sucking and air pumps, is near fifteen pounds on every square inch, so that if we could entirely squeeze out the air between our two hands, they would cling together with force equal to the pressure of double this weight, be-

 cause the air would press upon both hands; ; and if we could contrive to suck or squeeze out the air between one hand and the wall, the hand would stick fast to the wall. being pressed on it with weight above two hund

 red weight, that is, near l5 pounds on every square inch of the hand. By a late most cu- rious discovery of Sir sEverard Home, it is found that this is the very process by which flies and other insects of similar description are enabled to walk up purpendicuIar surfaces, however smooth, as the sides of walls and panes of glass in windows, and to walk as ea- silly along the ceiling of a room with their bO- dies dOwnwards and their feet over head. Their feet when examined by a microscope, are found to have fiat skin or flaps, like the feet of web-foOted animals, ,as ducks and geese; and they have towards the back part or heels, but inside of the skin or flap, two very small toes, so connected with the flap as to draw it close down upon the glass or wall the fly walks on, and to squeeze out the air com pletely, so that there is vacuum made be tween the foot and wall. The heconsequence is, that the air presses the foot on the wall with force greater than the weight of the fly,
ATMOSPHERIC PRESSURE.

|" In this work the most important part is to give them better religion. Knowing how strongly feel on this subject, you will not be surprised at my placing it foremost. But even if Christianity were out of the question, and if, when had wheeled away the rubbish of the old Pagodas, had nothing bt tier than simple deism to erect in their stead, should still feel some of the anxiety which now ur- ges me. It is necessary to see idoatry, to be fully sensible of its mischievous effects on the human mind. But of all idolatres which I have ever read or heard of, the religion of the Hindoos, in which have taken some pains to inform myself, really appears to me the worst, both in the degrading notions which it gives ofthe Deity in the endless rounds of it's burdensome ceremonies, which occupy the time and distract the thoughts, without either instructing or interesting it's votaries in the filthy acts of uncleanness and cruelty not on- ly permitted but enjoined, and inseparably in- terwoven with those ceremonies in the sys- than any thing else the devil has invented, to destroy the feelings of general benevolence, and to make nine-tenths of mankind the hopeless slaves of the remainder: and in to- tai absence of any system of morals, or any SiuSlc ltSSOH, WHICH Lllc peOple al IafGe ever hear, to live virtuOusly and to do good to each other. do not say, indeed that there are not some scattered lessons of this kind to be- found in their ancient books; but those books are neither accessible to the people at large, nor are these last permitted to read them: and, in general, all the sins which a Sudra is taught to fear, are, killing a COW, offending Brahmin,or neglecting one of the many frivolous rights by which their deities are supposed to be concilated. Accordingly though the general sobriety of the Hindoos, Ia virtue which they possess, in common with most inhabitants of warm clmates) affords a very great facility to the maintenance ofpub- lie order and decorum, realIys have never met with race of men whose standard ol morality is so low, who feel so little apparent shame in being detected in a afaIshood, or so little interest in the sufferings of neighbour not being of their own cast or family whose ordinary and familiar conversation is SO licen. tious or, in the wilder and more lawless districts, who shed blood with so little re. Dugnance."
CHARACTER OF THE HIDOOS. Bu the Lote B;slios Heber.

A curious circumstance in Natural History is related in the last number of the American Quarterly Review. The large winged grass hopper, which flutters with SO much vivacity through our meadows during the autumn, feeds upon vegitable matter, and deposits its eggs upon vegitables for the purpose of being supported until matured. Before the grass hopper takes wing, another insect, the ichneu- mon, alights upon its body,and rhrusts under it's skin a number of eggs, by means of tu- bula, awl shaped oviduct.-These eggs slow ly acquire perfection, become living worms, and feed upon the body of the hapless grass hopper, until themselves are ready to take wlng. So admirably do they perform their office, ,that they do not injure the vital organs of the insect they are internally devouring, until they are just ready to change their state; and at the proper season, hundreds of grasshoppers, in this condition, have just strength enough to futter to a tree or fence, and with a dying effort fix their hooked feet so firmly as to retain that position long after death. Examine their bodies at this season, and you will find an empty shell, or one filled with large and active worms, just ready to burst their coverings and become winged insects.

 The recently published number of the North American Review supplies us with a. nOther description of natural object, but lit- tie known, to common readers, though said to be familiar to the sight of those who navi- gate between the trophics-the beautiful ,and enigmatical insect, commonly named the Portugues man-of-war. It is from memoir by DOctar Tilesias, who accompanied M. de Krusenster, in his voyage around the world. "This singular animal had for several times been delineated, described, and endOw ed with names, yet not only its denOmina- tions were various, but also the nature and characteristic ascribed to it. According to some it was Polypus, according to others a ZoOphyte. and others ranged it among the Mollusca.-Naturalists who followed in the steps of Lime have called it the PhysGLis' Wonderful as is all the works of Providence, | admirably fitted as are the several parts of each created being for their several functions, complex in composition as they somtiemes at first seem, while yet they are always found l to be really so simple and suitable in their action, on a nearer investigation. we may nevertheless, venture to rank this little animat- ed creature among the most curious phenOm- ena of nature. A worm between and inches in length, which is found but in certain attitudes, has seemingly the skill and know ledge of an experienced navigator, and IS in | itself little ship. Its evolutions are accord ing to the winds; it raises and lowers its sail which is membrane provided with eleyating | and depressing organs. When filled with aiI it is so light, that it swims on the surface o alcohol, and is at the same time provided with structure, which furnishes it the neces- Sary ballast.

 When high winds would endanger its ex. istance, it descends into the deep. and is nev' CT seen on the surface of the water. From the under side of the body proceeds flores
NATURAL HISTORY.

was the daughter and heiress of the Lord of the Kienast, and the most blooming of Sile- sian beauties. Her wealth and charms attrac- ted crowds of knightly wOOers to her fathers castle; but the maiden, like another Camilla was entirely devoted to the bOsterOus exer- cises of the chase, in which she excelled many of her suitors she would hear no tale OflOve and dreaded marriage as she did prison. At length to free herself from all importunities, she made a solemn vow, never to give her hand but to the knight who would ride round the castle on the outer wall. Now, this wall is not only too narrow to furnish secure or pleasing promenade in many circumstances, but,throughOut nearly its whole course, it runs along the very brink of hideOus ,precipices, & in one place, hangs over the brink of a fright full abyss, which to this day, bears the name of Hell. The number of theslady's lovers rap idly diminished. The more prudent wisely considered, that the prize was not worth the rlsk; the vain proposed themselves to the tri- al,ln the hope that their presence would mol ify Cunigunda's heart and procure dispen- sation from the hard condition; but the mountain-beauty was proof against all arts, and when the moment of danger came, the courage of the suitor generally gave way. History has not recorded the precise number of those who actually made the attempt; it is only certain that every one of them broke his neck (as he well deserveda) and she lived on in her wild and virgin independence. At length young and handsome knight appear ed at the castle gate, and requested to be ad- mitted to the preseuce ofits mistress, that he might try his fortune. Cunigunda received him and her hour was come his manly beau ty, the courtesy ofhis behaviour, and his mo- ble spirit made her repent, for the first time, of the price which she had set upon her hand. Having received in presence of the in- mates of the castle her promlse to become his bride fine should return in safety from the trial, I,he rode forth to the wall, accompanied by the tears and wishes ofthe repentant beau- ty. In a short time shout from the menials announced that the adventu.e had been a. chieved and Cunigunda exulting that she was conquered hastened into the court, which the triumphant knight was just entering, to meet his ardent caresses.-Bat the knight stood aloof, gloomy and severe. "I can claim you," said he; "but am come, and have risked my life, not to win your hand but to humble your pride, ,and to punish your bar barity''-and tEereupOn he read her harsh lecture on the cruelty and arrogance of her conduct towards her suit0rs. The spirit of chivalry weeps at recording, that he finished his oration in giving the astonished beauty a box on the ear, sprung into his saddle, and galloped forth from the gate. It was the Landgrave Albert of Thuringia, already a married man, and who had long trained his favorite steed to this perilous exercise. The memory of the ulterior fate of Cunigunda has not survived.

BOTANICAL QUESTION.

which extend twenty feet in length, and arc so elastic and delicate, that they wind tn 8 spiral form like screw, serving at once as anchors, defensive and offensive weapons pneumatic tubes, and feelers. The insect has the colOrs of the rainbow; its crest, which per forms the office of a sail, is intersected with pink and blue veins, trimmed with rosy border, ,and swelIs with the wind, or at the ani- mal's pleasure. The flores contain "a viscOus matter, which has the property of stinging like nettles and produces postules. It acts so strongly. that vessels in which they have been kept for time must he repeatedly washed before they can be used. These f. bres may be cut off without deprvng them or the rest of the insect of the principal of life; and the separation takes place sponta- neously ,wheneyer the glutinous m ,tter comes in contact with hard surface like the sides of a glass globe. The insect however has dan gerous enemies in small dolphins, and medu- ses, againstswhich neither its, nautical skill nor it's poison can defend it. To the natural philosopher. this little animal is a curious ex- empiifcaEion of the principles of hydrosta

 tics ana of hygrometry, as it's bladder is pre- haps among the best substances that can be used for the instruments of the latter science. AO ehe PhySioIOSiSL u laS tue Sau1e import ance as the rest of that class of beings, of which every part is endowed with an uncommonly strong principle of vitality, and which have therefore not improperly been called biota by Doctor Hill. To contemplative mind, the wonderful organization of the Physalis must be new proof that hardly any great effort of human ingenuity, perseverance, courage and skill. is without a duplicate of more as- tonishing workmanship, simplicity and saga city, m beings coming from the hand of the Author of Creation. If navigation is justly deemed the most daring enterprise of man, it may be considered as remedy against pride to know that there exists worm. which an all powerful Providence had at once made navigator and ship, hydros- tic and pneumatic engine. being destitute of mind, and yet one that watches the winds, and rides on the waves.-Bost. IMPENITENCE AND REPENTANCE. There is darkness, fearful as the tomb, That shrouds the mind of stern Impenitence: No shadowy phantoms fit in doubtful gloom; But solid blackness presses on the sense. But more appalling to the bleaching eye The awful scene 'tis fated to survey; When Truths bright flashes bursting from on high, Pour o'er the waste of life their gancng ray. 0, scene of horrors Der gulph to stand, [frame ]! Whose crumbling verge scarce stays hIs totterlng Cliffs rise, and chasms yawn on every hand And torrents pour beneath their f0amlng stream. Around unnumbered horrid monsters glare, Scarce seen ere swallowed in returning night: The unhappy wretch behods destruction near; But whether shall he urge his darkling flight! o star of mercy! Rise and point his way, As, when to lead the Sheperds to their Lord, Above the lowly roof where Jesus lay,

 Far through the gloom thy cheering was poured Lost in the glare of gay prosperity

 That mild and tender beam had valnly shone: How welcome now it meets his aching eye, Towering serenely bright OCT mercy's throne Though faint the ray, disclosing nought beside, Nor threatening dangers, nor the path he treads, With greatfu heart he halls the heavenly Guide That to a Saviour's fostering bosom leads. There sheltered from the ruthless tempests wrath, By Faith redeemed, in humble hope secure, The bowling fends that late beset his path, Shuddering, but safe, he hears and fears no more.

 T. B. N.

 On scanty and bold projection fthe rock sand the ruins of the Kienast' so seperated on all sides from tiie bOdy of the mountain sy precipitous delis.excePt where narrow ledge on the south connects 1t with the hill, that the rising of single draw bridge must have rendered it utterly inaccessible. Enough of the outer wall still remains,tO preserve the memory of the fair Cunigunda, equally cele- brated for Der charms and her cruelty. She

| enabled to climb the perpendicuarland smooth surface of the ice-hilis among which they liye.-Some kinds of lizards have the same power of climbing, and of creeping with their bodies dOwnwards, along the ceiling of room. In the large feet of these animals, the cOntrivance is easily observed of the two toes or tightners, by which the skin of the foot is pinned down, and the air excluded in the act of walking or climbing; but it is the very same, only upon larger scale, with the mechan- ism of fy's or butterhy's foot; and both operations, the climbing of the sea-horse on the ice, and the creeping of the fly on the window or the ceiling, are performed exactly by the same power, the weight of the atmos- phere.-London paper.

 AWFUL OcCURRENCE.--Ont the 2Sth A. pril James Ackley, a collier, in the service of Mir. Scrowcrott, of Hindley near Wigan,died under circumstances extremely awful. Ackley was person greatly addicted to the vice of swearing. On the 22d uIt. his wife was taken i'll, but he had no sympathy for her sufferings and told her that she was ' foring." On the Sunday following she died. On the next day the son paid him a visit, and the father said to him ''John, thy step-mother hath tricked me, thought to have died first, but never mind, l shall die before they take her out of the house." At this time he appeared to be troubled with no complaint but that what he called his d-d asthma. His son earnestly re- monstrated with him for his wickedness.and implored him to think of future state, but without effect. He said thereSwas '.nei- ther God, nor devil, nor heaven or he'll" that if there was one he was an unjust one, or he was asleep and had forgotten us. The son nl- ho hardened in unbelief. On Tuesday the 27th he was often heard to mutter dreadful oaths, which were principally directed to his chil- dren. On Wednesday, the day on which his wife's funeral took place, he lay on the squab Ia sort of sofa,) quite speeches.. A neighbor who came to attend the funeral said it was time to serve out the bread, Ia custom on such occasions in that part of the country,) when sudden change took place in his bo- dy. All the persons present arose to look at him; he presented dreadful spectacle, when, awful to relate, in less than two min- utcs he breathed his last. 1t is more easy to conceive than to describe the feelings of the bystanders on witnessing this awful visitation of the Almighty ty.-Mancheste Mercury.

 WondertM recipe.-A remedy for the bite of mad dog has been discovered in France The Roman Catholic missionaries at.Nantes seem to be trading company, Ethey sell re- licts, chaplets, and even "letters of Jesus Christ :" one of which was found in the cha pei of St. Hubert. the lst of Feb. 1926 its sold as preservative against hydrophobia! It concludes as follows ;--" All persons who shall carry copy of this letter about him in honor of St. Hubert will be preserved from the bite of all mad animals. All persons who can't read may say five paters and five ave marias, d uring five Fridays. in honor of five wounds of Jesus Christ as it is marked in the

 letter. Approved by the grand vicar-general, at the holy see; signed Dubois and Maler, bishops and archbishops of Paris. price one penny." Certainly no one can be cured at a cheaper rate, and have such letter into the bargain. How it came to be found out that this letter was. good for the bite of mad dog we are not told. '..

 Effects 0f Iutemperdnce.-A widow woman between forty and fifty years of age, residing dren's sake we forbear to mention, retired to a state of intoxication. About midnight she arose, left her chamber. and knocked for ad- mission, (to obtain, as she said, light,) at the door of another apartment of the same house. Not being able by her entreaties to obtain an enterance, she declared with aa oath, that unless her request was granted she would throw herself from her window which rash determination she deliberately put into execution, by forcing off a part ofthe window easement in the third story, taking out the lower sash and placing under the window n large trunk, from which she jumped into the street. The fall upon the pavement caused the rupture of blood vessel, and though

 medical aid was immediately called and eve ] ry means used to restore her, she lived but a ] few hours.-Bos. Iray.

 sary for the prosecution oftheir design; such

 as barometers, theOdolites. chrOnOmeter,

 SSc. and passed the night at the Village of A.

From the JWuerHe Maguzine.

 HARRY THE APPRENTICE.

 Twenty years ago knew Henry Mandin. He was the son of very poor man, and at the age of thirteen was bound an apprentice to a respectable mechanic in neighbOuring village. He was active and ingenious. He was faithful to his work, and consequently found many leisure hours for sporting with other boys of the village. Several months passed away and Harry seemed to enjoy this tune extremely well. He, however, would sometimes mediate very seriously on the manner in which he had spent his leisure time.

 One night after he had gone to bed he lay awake for an hour or two. He said to himself, "What good will all this play do me ? shall by and by be man, and then shall know but little more than barely to work my usual hours and then play like boy.' After many such firm reflections he fell asleep. He awoke the next morning with the thoughts fresh on his mind and rose with the determination to devote but half as much time as usual to sport and the rest of his spare time he would spend in reading books, if he could find any one who would lend him. He finished his regular portion of work for that day long before surdown. He then went to Esq. Tisdale, (whO was very good man) and asked him if he would lend him some books to read.-Esq. T. looked at him a moment with little surprise. yet with smile on his face. "And why do you wish books to read ?" said he. Because" said HaTy, II have several hours spare time, du- ring the week, which usually spend with my pIayfellows; but was thinking last night, it would be great deal better for ne to spend part of the time in reading some books, that will do me good when become a man. have no money to buy them, and if you, Sir will he good enough to lend me one to begin with, will use it very carefully ,and be much obliged to you.

 The good man was always delighted with an opportunity of doing good; and the honest simplicity of the boy in making this applica- ton heightened his pleasure in granting the request. He not only lent him an interesting little volume for that week, but promised him the use of any books he might wish to read.

 Harry went home with this precious treas ure and began to read. He became so well pleased with the book, that he spent very lit- tie time in the company of his mates. He re- turned the volume and took another. .and sev- eral weeks passed in similar manner. They could not but miss him, as he had been the must active among them. After learning the reason ofthis absence, they began to laugh at him and asked him If he was going to turn Methodist? Harry had naturally proud heart, and was not altogether pleased with their ridicule. One night he considered a long time, after he had went to bed, doubtful whether he should keep to his favorite pursuit of reading, or yield to the entreaties of his friends, and spend all his spare time in play. He fell asleep without coming to any conclu- sion. The next morning he awoke, and thought of the subject few minutes before he arose. It took him but short time to decide. He bounced out of bed-snapped his fingers as sign ofhs resolution. :. Whats all their nonsense to me ?" said he, they may call me Methodist ifthey please will get my knowledge in spite of them. Ihey may have their play and I'll have my book so good bye to ye, my lads, I'll not go with you at all now.' He quit their company, and month after month, and year after year, he pursued a course ofreading which stored his mind with the most valuable information. Esq. T. sought many occasions of conversing with him about what he had read and open ed his mind to that all important subject which relates to the immortality of the soul, and of the only way to escape eternal punish ment. He lent him religious books. The effort was not lost. The Holy Spirit accom- panied proper means, and Harry became a penitent believer in the Lord Jesus Christ.

 Youthful reader, would you like to know what has become of Harry? He is now one ofthe most respectable men in our country. His knowledge is extensive,an his society is sought and esteemed by all good men. By his industry he has acquired competent for tune. He has enough to support his family, and to supply the wants ofthe poor and affiic- ted around him. He is, indeed, a happy man h,ncause his house is the house of prayer ---h,, loves the bible and his God, and is constantly looking forward to the day of his death, as to day that will introduce him to the glories of the heavenly world, where are the saints and angels of the Lord, and where his Jesus dwells to receive all those who love and serve him,into mansions of ev- erlasting happiness.

From the Jupenile Magazine. HARRY THE APPRENTICE.

A French botanist says, that the leaves of lettuce, the rose, bramble, dandelion hop, hemp and fig will keep silk alive, though they will not enable it to produce silk. According this writer, it is the resinous matter contained in the mulberry leaves, which, undergoing change in the stomach of the worm, enables it to form silk.

of the clover and vetches p the ground and on. ly waited for stimulous tO geTminate But how did it come there We know that high and arid heaths never poduce clover it cannot therefore be consd- cred proceeding from plant which formerly grew there. But should admit the possibility that these kinds of earth may conan clover seed, this O. pnon cannot be maintained in some parts of East Fresand where wild clover is made to grow by strew ing pearl ashes peat marshes Bulletin Unirers0L 6eS Scipnce,

l never sought days rep0se

 But some sharp thorn soon pierced my breast never watched the evenings close,

 And hoped heaven of rest, But soon darkling cloud would come

 Athwart the prospect bright, And, pale as twilight on tomb,

 My hopes grew dim in night, Off have mark'd the heav'nly moon

 Wandering her painless way Along the midnight's purple noon,

 More far-more loved than day; But soon she flung her shadowy wreath Der dark eternity, As faint smile on the cheek of death, 'Twixt hope and agony. Ev'n so the mirth of man is madness;-

 His joy as a sepuiChrai light Which shows his solitude and sadness, But chaseth not the night. THE DISTANT SFiP.-BY MRS. HEMANs. The sea birds wing Der ocean's breast

 Shoots like glancng star, While the red radiance of the West.

 Spreads, kindling fast and far; And yet that splendor wins thee not

 Thy still and thoughtful eye Dwells but on one dark distant spot

 Of all the main and sky. Look round thee! e!-oer the sumberng deep A solemn glory broods, \ fire hath touched the beacon steep,

 And all the golden woods; A thousand gorgeous clouds on high

 Burn with the amber light; What spell from the rich pagcanry,

 Chains down the gazing sight! X christening thought of human cares, A feeling linked to earth! Is not your speck barque, which bears

 The loved of many hearth? Oh! do not hope, and grief, and fear

 Crown her frail world even now, And manhood's prayer, and woman's tear Follow her venturous prov! Bright are the floating clouds above, The giitttering seas below; Bm we are b. ,und by cords of love, To kindred, veal and wo! Therefore, amidst thus %lld array Of glorious things antt taIr' Nv soul is on the barque's lone way Tzeoy '. ,.uman hearts are there.
STANZAS.

full articles.headline: ATMOSPHERIC PRESSURE.
full articles.article:
The pressure or weight of the atmosphere, as shown by the barOmetar, the sucking and air pumps, is near fifteen pounds on every square inch, so that if we could entirely squeeze out the air between our two hands, they would cling together with force equal to the pressure of double this weight, be-

 cause the air would press upon both hands; ; and if we could contrive to suck or squeeze out the air between one hand and the wall, the hand would stick fast to the wall. being pressed on it with weight above two hund

 red weight, that is, near l5 pounds on every square inch of the hand. By a late most cu- rious discovery of Sir sEverard Home, it is found that this is the very process by which flies and other insects of similar description are enabled to walk up purpendicuIar surfaces, however smooth, as the sides of walls and panes of glass in windows, and to walk as ea- silly along the ceiling of a room with their bO- dies dOwnwards and their feet over head. Their feet when examined by a microscope, are found to have fiat skin or flaps, like the feet of web-foOted animals, ,as ducks and geese; and they have towards the back part or heels, but inside of the skin or flap, two very small toes, so connected with the flap as to draw it close down upon the glass or wall the fly walks on, and to squeeze out the air com pletely, so that there is vacuum made be tween the foot and wall. The heconsequence is, that the air presses the foot on the wall with force greater than the weight of the fly,

full articles.article: |" In this work the most important part is to give them better religion. Knowing how strongly feel on this subject, you will not be surprised at my placing it foremost. But even if Christianity were out of the question, and if, when had wheeled away the rubbish of the old Pagodas, had nothing bt tier than simple deism to erect in their stead, should still feel some of the anxiety which now ur- ges me. It is necessary to see idoatry, to be fully sensible of its mischievous effects on the human mind. But of all idolatres which I have ever read or heard of, the religion of the Hindoos, in which have taken some pains to inform myself, really appears to me the worst, both in the degrading notions which it gives ofthe Deity in the endless rounds of it's burdensome ceremonies, which occupy the time and distract the thoughts, without either instructing or interesting it's votaries in the filthy acts of uncleanness and cruelty not on- ly permitted but enjoined, and inseparably in- terwoven with those ceremonies in the sys- than any thing else the devil has invented, to destroy the feelings of general benevolence, and to make nine-tenths of mankind the hopeless slaves of the remainder: and in to- tai absence of any system of morals, or any SiuSlc ltSSOH, WHICH Lllc peOple al IafGe ever hear, to live virtuOusly and to do good to each other. do not say, indeed that there are not some scattered lessons of this kind to be- found in their ancient books; but those books are neither accessible to the people at large, nor are these last permitted to read them: and, in general, all the sins which a Sudra is taught to fear, are, killing a COW, offending Brahmin,or neglecting one of the many frivolous rights by which their deities are supposed to be concilated. Accordingly though the general sobriety of the Hindoos, Ia virtue which they possess, in common with most inhabitants of warm clmates) affords a very great facility to the maintenance ofpub- lie order and decorum, realIys have never met with race of men whose standard ol morality is so low, who feel so little apparent shame in being detected in a afaIshood, or so little interest in the sufferings of neighbour not being of their own cast or family whose ordinary and familiar conversation is SO licen. tious or, in the wilder and more lawless districts, who shed blood with so little re. Dugnance."

full articles.headline: NATURAL HISTORY.
full articles.article:
A curious circumstance in Natural History is related in the last number of the American Quarterly Review. The large winged grass hopper, which flutters with SO much vivacity through our meadows during the autumn, feeds upon vegitable matter, and deposits its eggs upon vegitables for the purpose of being supported until matured. Before the grass hopper takes wing, another insect, the ichneu- mon, alights upon its body,and rhrusts under it's skin a number of eggs, by means of tu- bula, awl shaped oviduct.-These eggs slow ly acquire perfection, become living worms, and feed upon the body of the hapless grass hopper, until themselves are ready to take wlng. So admirably do they perform their office, ,that they do not injure the vital organs of the insect they are internally devouring, until they are just ready to change their state; and at the proper season, hundreds of grasshoppers, in this condition, have just strength enough to futter to a tree or fence, and with a dying effort fix their hooked feet so firmly as to retain that position long after death. Examine their bodies at this season, and you will find an empty shell, or one filled with large and active worms, just ready to burst their coverings and become winged insects.

 The recently published number of the North American Review supplies us with a. nOther description of natural object, but lit- tie known, to common readers, though said to be familiar to the sight of those who navi- gate between the trophics-the beautiful ,and enigmatical insect, commonly named the Portugues man-of-war. It is from memoir by DOctar Tilesias, who accompanied M. de Krusenster, in his voyage around the world. "This singular animal had for several times been delineated, described, and endOw ed with names, yet not only its denOmina- tions were various, but also the nature and characteristic ascribed to it. According to some it was Polypus, according to others a ZoOphyte. and others ranged it among the Mollusca.-Naturalists who followed in the steps of Lime have called it the PhysGLis' Wonderful as is all the works of Providence, | admirably fitted as are the several parts of each created being for their several functions, complex in composition as they somtiemes at first seem, while yet they are always found l to be really so simple and suitable in their action, on a nearer investigation. we may nevertheless, venture to rank this little animat- ed creature among the most curious phenOm- ena of nature. A worm between and inches in length, which is found but in certain attitudes, has seemingly the skill and know ledge of an experienced navigator, and IS in | itself little ship. Its evolutions are accord ing to the winds; it raises and lowers its sail which is membrane provided with eleyating | and depressing organs. When filled with aiI it is so light, that it swims on the surface o alcohol, and is at the same time provided with structure, which furnishes it the neces- Sary ballast.

 When high winds would endanger its ex. istance, it descends into the deep. and is nev' CT seen on the surface of the water. From the under side of the body proceeds flores

was the daughter and heiress of the Lord of the Kienast, and the most blooming of Sile- sian beauties. Her wealth and charms attrac- ted crowds of knightly wOOers to her fathers castle; but the maiden, like another Camilla was entirely devoted to the bOsterOus exer- cises of the chase, in which she excelled many of her suitors she would hear no tale OflOve and dreaded marriage as she did prison. At length to free herself from all importunities, she made a solemn vow, never to give her hand but to the knight who would ride round the castle on the outer wall. Now, this wall is not only too narrow to furnish secure or pleasing promenade in many circumstances, but,throughOut nearly its whole course, it runs along the very brink of hideOus ,precipices, & in one place, hangs over the brink of a fright full abyss, which to this day, bears the name of Hell. The number of theslady's lovers rap idly diminished. The more prudent wisely considered, that the prize was not worth the rlsk; the vain proposed themselves to the tri- al,ln the hope that their presence would mol ify Cunigunda's heart and procure dispen- sation from the hard condition; but the mountain-beauty was proof against all arts, and when the moment of danger came, the courage of the suitor generally gave way. History has not recorded the precise number of those who actually made the attempt; it is only certain that every one of them broke his neck (as he well deserveda) and she lived on in her wild and virgin independence. At length young and handsome knight appear ed at the castle gate, and requested to be ad- mitted to the preseuce ofits mistress, that he might try his fortune. Cunigunda received him and her hour was come his manly beau ty, the courtesy ofhis behaviour, and his mo- ble spirit made her repent, for the first time, of the price which she had set upon her hand. Having received in presence of the in- mates of the castle her promlse to become his bride fine should return in safety from the trial, I,he rode forth to the wall, accompanied by the tears and wishes ofthe repentant beau- ty. In a short time shout from the menials announced that the adventu.e had been a. chieved and Cunigunda exulting that she was conquered hastened into the court, which the triumphant knight was just entering, to meet his ardent caresses.-Bat the knight stood aloof, gloomy and severe. "I can claim you," said he; "but am come, and have risked my life, not to win your hand but to humble your pride, ,and to punish your bar barity''-and tEereupOn he read her harsh lecture on the cruelty and arrogance of her conduct towards her suit0rs. The spirit of chivalry weeps at recording, that he finished his oration in giving the astonished beauty a box on the ear, sprung into his saddle, and galloped forth from the gate. It was the Landgrave Albert of Thuringia, already a married man, and who had long trained his favorite steed to this perilous exercise. The memory of the ulterior fate of Cunigunda has not survived.

full articles.article: The &rdDers of GeAea, Florence, Ve9ise' Sc &c. choose n orange tree whch he deprive of its oe Dha. length, and also through the roots to the arf a rnond. with double flowers, fig trees, rose tee' nyL flcs, and other ornamental plants are selected icH they arrange in or threes according to fancy ana the size of the aperture iR the orange tree, and pia mate, passing them through the orange tree, 90 that the plants may reach short distance above the up- per end of the trunk; the roots of the tree are then Covered with earth, Natered and cultivated, as If 1t were tree just planted. The and all the young plants then grow together aad will live for ten or fifteen years

full articles.headline: BOTANICAL QUESTION.
full articles.article:
Are all plants the result of germinaton of seed or x;ro;n earth andvegtsble mould , It is undoubtedly a very w remarkable phenomenoa that the earth when dug to the depth of eight or ten feet or more prodG

 evposed to the sun; but what is more extraordinary, is thai the new yegtatOn frequently produces plants of kinds which have never been, remarked in the coupy is natural to ask whence hen o come ne these these psw nlants were contained in the several kinds of tSe earthl But could all those seeds, which have been perhaps above three thousand years nader ground without having been exposed to the acton 0i the sun

 ashes on high and arid heaths, we should see some

 lime afterwards clover and vetehes growing there, though those two plants had never before been seen on those two places. Shall Ve believe that me seecs

which extend twenty feet in length, and arc so elastic and delicate, that they wind tn 8 spiral form like screw, serving at once as anchors, defensive and offensive weapons pneumatic tubes, and feelers. The insect has the colOrs of the rainbow; its crest, which per forms the office of a sail, is intersected with pink and blue veins, trimmed with rosy border, ,and swelIs with the wind, or at the ani- mal's pleasure. The flores contain "a viscOus matter, which has the property of stinging like nettles and produces postules. It acts so strongly. that vessels in which they have been kept for time must he repeatedly washed before they can be used. These f. bres may be cut off without deprvng them or the rest of the insect of the principal of life; and the separation takes place sponta- neously ,wheneyer the glutinous m ,tter comes in contact with hard surface like the sides of a glass globe. The insect however has dan gerous enemies in small dolphins, and medu- ses, againstswhich neither its, nautical skill nor it's poison can defend it. To the natural philosopher. this little animal is a curious ex- empiifcaEion of the principles of hydrosta

 tics ana of hygrometry, as it's bladder is pre- haps among the best substances that can be used for the instruments of the latter science. AO ehe PhySioIOSiSL u laS tue Sau1e import ance as the rest of that class of beings, of which every part is endowed with an uncommonly strong principle of vitality, and which have therefore not improperly been called biota by Doctor Hill. To contemplative mind, the wonderful organization of the Physalis must be new proof that hardly any great effort of human ingenuity, perseverance, courage and skill. is without a duplicate of more as- tonishing workmanship, simplicity and saga city, m beings coming from the hand of the Author of Creation. If navigation is justly deemed the most daring enterprise of man, it may be considered as remedy against pride to know that there exists worm. which an all powerful Providence had at once made navigator and ship, hydros- tic and pneumatic engine. being destitute of mind, and yet one that watches the winds, and rides on the waves.-Bost. Coer.

full articles.headline:
ADVERTISING.

From tue Boston Recorder. IMPENITENCE AND REPENTANCE.
full articles.article:
IMPENITENCE AND REPENTANCE. There is darkness, fearful as the tomb, That shrouds the mind of stern Impenitence: No shadowy phantoms fit in doubtful gloom; But solid blackness presses on the sense. But more appalling to the bleaching eye The awful scene 'tis fated to survey; When Truths bright flashes bursting from on high, Pour o'er the waste of life their gancng ray. 0, scene of horrors Der gulph to stand, [frame ]! Whose crumbling verge scarce stays hIs totterlng Cliffs rise, and chasms yawn on every hand And torrents pour beneath their f0amlng stream. Around unnumbered horrid monsters glare, Scarce seen ere swallowed in returning night: The unhappy wretch behods destruction near; But whether shall he urge his darkling flight! o star of mercy! Rise and point his way, As, when to lead the Sheperds to their Lord, Above the lowly roof where Jesus lay,

 Far through the gloom thy cheering was poured Lost in the glare of gay prosperity

 That mild and tender beam had valnly shone: How welcome now it meets his aching eye, Towering serenely bright OCT mercy's throne Though faint the ray, disclosing nought beside, Nor threatening dangers, nor the path he treads, With greatfu heart he halls the heavenly Guide That to a Saviour's fostering bosom leads. There sheltered from the ruthless tempests wrath, By Faith redeemed, in humble hope secure, The bowling fends that late beset his path, Shuddering, but safe, he hears and fears no more.

 T. B. N.

full articles.headline: ctJN1GUNDA AND HER LOVERS.
full articles.article:
MT Russell, in describing the Schneekoppe, a b;eh mouutais in Silesia introduces the following

 ..# z

 On scanty and bold projection fthe rock sand the ruins of the Kienast' so seperated on all sides from tiie bOdy of the mountain sy precipitous delis.excePt where narrow ledge on the south connects 1t with the hill, that the rising of single draw bridge must have rendered it utterly inaccessible. Enough of the outer wall still remains,tO preserve the memory of the fair Cunigunda, equally cele- brated for Der charms and her cruelty. She

| enabled to climb the perpendicuarland smooth surface of the ice-hilis among which they liye.-Some kinds of lizards have the same power of climbing, and of creeping with their bodies dOwnwards, along the ceiling of room. In the large feet of these animals, the cOntrivance is easily observed of the two toes or tightners, by which the skin of the foot is pinned down, and the air excluded in the act of walking or climbing; but it is the very same, only upon larger scale, with the mechan- ism of fy's or butterhy's foot; and both operations, the climbing of the sea-horse on the ice, and the creeping of the fly on the window or the ceiling, are performed exactly by the same power, the weight of the atmos- phere.-London paper.

 AWFUL OcCURRENCE.--Ont the 2Sth A. pril James Ackley, a collier, in the service of Mir. Scrowcrott, of Hindley near Wigan,died under circumstances extremely awful. Ackley was person greatly addicted to the vice of swearing. On the 22d uIt. his wife was taken i'll, but he had no sympathy for her sufferings and told her that she was ' foring." On the Sunday following she died. On the next day the son paid him a visit, and the father said to him ''John, thy step-mother hath tricked me, thought to have died first, but never mind, l shall die before they take her out of the house." At this time he appeared to be troubled with no complaint but that what he called his d-d asthma. His son earnestly re- monstrated with him for his wickedness.and implored him to think of future state, but without effect. He said thereSwas '.nei- ther God, nor devil, nor heaven or he'll" that if there was one he was an unjust one, or he was asleep and had forgotten us. The son nl- ho hardened in unbelief. On Tuesday the 27th he was often heard to mutter dreadful oaths, which were principally directed to his chil- dren. On Wednesday, the day on which his wife's funeral took place, he lay on the squab Ia sort of sofa,) quite speeches.. A neighbor who came to attend the funeral said it was time to serve out the bread, Ia custom on such occasions in that part of the country,) when sudden change took place in his bo- dy. All the persons present arose to look at him; he presented dreadful spectacle, when, awful to relate, in less than two min- utcs he breathed his last. 1t is more easy to conceive than to describe the feelings of the bystanders on witnessing this awful visitation of the Almighty ty.-Mancheste Mercury.

 WondertM recipe.-A remedy for the bite of mad dog has been discovered in France The Roman Catholic missionaries at.Nantes seem to be trading company, Ethey sell re- licts, chaplets, and even "letters of Jesus Christ :" one of which was found in the cha pei of St. Hubert. the lst of Feb. 1926 its sold as preservative against hydrophobia! It concludes as follows ;--" All persons who shall carry copy of this letter about him in honor of St. Hubert will be preserved from the bite of all mad animals. All persons who can't read may say five paters and five ave marias, d uring five Fridays. in honor of five wounds of Jesus Christ as it is marked in the

 letter. Approved by the grand vicar-general, at the holy see; signed Dubois and Maler, bishops and archbishops of Paris. price one penny." Certainly no one can be cured at a cheaper rate, and have such letter into the bargain. How it came to be found out that this letter was. good for the bite of mad dog we are not told. '..

 Effects 0f Iutemperdnce.-A widow woman between forty and fifty years of age, residing dren's sake we forbear to mention, retired to a state of intoxication. About midnight she arose, left her chamber. and knocked for ad- mission, (to obtain, as she said, light,) at the door of another apartment of the same house. Not being able by her entreaties to obtain an enterance, she declared with aa oath, that unless her request was granted she would throw herself from her window which rash determination she deliberately put into execution, by forcing off a part ofthe window easement in the third story, taking out the lower sash and placing under the window n large trunk, from which she jumped into the street. The fall upon the pavement caused the rupture of blood vessel, and though

 medical aid was immediately called and eve ] ry means used to restore her, she lived but a ] few hours.-Bos. Iray.

 l From the Baltimore Gazete.

 In the Mercury of the 17th May,published at Vera Cruz, we have the following account of the ascent of Messrs. Wm and Frederick

 Glennie, in the employ of the mining compa-

 ny and MT. John Taylor of Mexico, to the

 summit of the celebrated volcano of POpOca-

 tepetr It may be proper to remark here,

 that ofthe many attempts that have been

 made to reach the top of this stupendous

 volcano, the present is the only one that has

 succeeded. The account is given in an ex tract from the journal of the gentlemen who

 conducted the interesting enterprise. On the

 morning of the 18th May they left Mex

 icO, provided with all the instruments neces-

 sary for the prosecution oftheir design; such

 as barometers, theOdolites. chrOnOmeter,

 SSc. and passed the night at the Village of A.

full articles.headline: From the Jupenile Magazine. HARRY THE APPRENTICE.
full articles.article:
From the JWuerHe Maguzine.

 HARRY THE APPRENTICE.

 Twenty years ago knew Henry Mandin. He was the son of very poor man, and at the age of thirteen was bound an apprentice to a respectable mechanic in neighbOuring village. He was active and ingenious. He was faithful to his work, and consequently found many leisure hours for sporting with other boys of the village. Several months passed away and Harry seemed to enjoy this tune extremely well. He, however, would sometimes mediate very seriously on the manner in which he had spent his leisure time.

 One night after he had gone to bed he lay awake for an hour or two. He said to himself, "What good will all this play do me ? shall by and by be man, and then shall know but little more than barely to work my usual hours and then play like boy.' After many such firm reflections he fell asleep. He awoke the next morning with the thoughts fresh on his mind and rose with the determination to devote but half as much time as usual to sport and the rest of his spare time he would spend in reading books, if he could find any one who would lend him. He finished his regular portion of work for that day long before surdown. He then went to Esq. Tisdale, (whO was very good man) and asked him if he would lend him some books to read.-Esq. T. looked at him a moment with little surprise. yet with smile on his face. "And why do you wish books to read ?" said he. Because" said HaTy, II have several hours spare time, du- ring the week, which usually spend with my pIayfellows; but was thinking last night, it would be great deal better for ne to spend part of the time in reading some books, that will do me good when become a man. have no money to buy them, and if you, Sir will he good enough to lend me one to begin with, will use it very carefully ,and be much obliged to you.

 The good man was always delighted with an opportunity of doing good; and the honest simplicity of the boy in making this applica- ton heightened his pleasure in granting the request. He not only lent him an interesting little volume for that week, but promised him the use of any books he might wish to read.

 Harry went home with this precious treas ure and began to read. He became so well pleased with the book, that he spent very lit- tie time in the company of his mates. He re- turned the volume and took another. .and sev- eral weeks passed in similar manner. They could not but miss him, as he had been the must active among them. After learning the reason ofthis absence, they began to laugh at him and asked him If he was going to turn Methodist? Harry had naturally proud heart, and was not altogether pleased with their ridicule. One night he considered a long time, after he had went to bed, doubtful whether he should keep to his favorite pursuit of reading, or yield to the entreaties of his friends, and spend all his spare time in play. He fell asleep without coming to any conclu- sion. The next morning he awoke, and thought of the subject few minutes before he arose. It took him but short time to decide. He bounced out of bed-snapped his fingers as sign ofhs resolution. :. Whats all their nonsense to me ?" said he, they may call me Methodist ifthey please will get my knowledge in spite of them. Ihey may have their play and I'll have my book so good bye to ye, my lads, I'll not go with you at all now.' He quit their company, and month after month, and year after year, he pursued a course ofreading which stored his mind with the most valuable information. Esq. T. sought many occasions of conversing with him about what he had read and open ed his mind to that all important subject which relates to the immortality of the soul, and of the only way to escape eternal punish ment. He lent him religious books. The effort was not lost. The Holy Spirit accom- panied proper means, and Harry became a penitent believer in the Lord Jesus Christ.

 Youthful reader, would you like to know what has become of Harry? He is now one ofthe most respectable men in our country. His knowledge is extensive,an his society is sought and esteemed by all good men. By his industry he has acquired competent for tune. He has enough to support his family, and to supply the wants ofthe poor and affiic- ted around him. He is, indeed, a happy man h,ncause his house is the house of prayer ---h,, loves the bible and his God, and is constantly looking forward to the day of his death, as to day that will introduce him to the glories of the heavenly world, where are the saints and angels of the Lord, and where his Jesus dwells to receive all those who love and serve him,into mansions of ev- erlasting happiness.

 CUNIGUNDA AND HER LOVERS. Kjr Russell, in describing the Scbneekoppe, a h;os mountain in Silesia, introduces the following story -, On scanty and bold projection Ofthe rock stand the ruins of the Kienast, so seperated on all sides from tfie body of the mountain Sy precipitous delis except where narrow ledge on the south connects it with the hill, that tbe rising of a single draw bridge must

A French botanist says, that the leaves of lettuce, the rose, bramble, dandelion hop, hemp and fig will keep silk alive, though they will not enable it to produce silk. According this writer, it is the resinous matter contained in the mulberry leaves, which, undergoing change in the stomach of the worm, enables it to form silk.

of the clover and vetches p the ground and on. ly waited for stimulous tO geTminate But how did it come there We know that high and arid heaths never poduce clover it cannot therefore be consd- cred proceeding from plant which formerly grew there. But should admit the possibility that these kinds of earth may conan clover seed, this O. pnon cannot be maintained in some parts of East Fresand where wild clover is made to grow by strew ing pearl ashes peat marshes Bulletin Unirers0L 6eS Scipnce,

full articles.headline: STANZAS.
full articles.article:
l never sought days rep0se

 But some sharp thorn soon pierced my breast never watched the evenings close,

 And hoped heaven of rest, But soon darkling cloud would come

 Athwart the prospect bright, And, pale as twilight on tomb,

 My hopes grew dim in night, Off have mark'd the heav'nly moon

 Wandering her painless way Along the midnight's purple noon,

 More far-more loved than day; But soon she flung her shadowy wreath Der dark eternity, As faint smile on the cheek of death, 'Twixt hope and agony. Ev'n so the mirth of man is madness;-

 His joy as a sepuiChrai light Which shows his solitude and sadness, But chaseth not the night. THE DISTANT SFiP.-BY MRS. HEMANs. The sea birds wing Der ocean's breast

 Shoots like glancng star, While the red radiance of the West.

 Spreads, kindling fast and far; And yet that splendor wins thee not

 Thy still and thoughtful eye Dwells but on one dark distant spot

 Of all the main and sky. Look round thee! e!-oer the sumberng deep A solemn glory broods, \ fire hath touched the beacon steep,

 And all the golden woods; A thousand gorgeous clouds on high

 Burn with the amber light; What spell from the rich pagcanry,

 Chains down the gazing sight! X christening thought of human cares, A feeling linked to earth! Is not your speck barque, which bears

 The loved of many hearth? Oh! do not hope, and grief, and fear

 Crown her frail world even now, And manhood's prayer, and woman's tear Follow her venturous prov! Bright are the floating clouds above, The giitttering seas below; Bm we are b. ,und by cords of love, To kindred, veal and wo! Therefore, amidst thus %lld array Of glorious things antt taIr' Nv soul is on the barque's lone way Tzeoy '. ,.uman hearts are there.
